           <dt>&#x22d9; tattva </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;tva</em> n. true or real state, truth, reality &#x015a;vetUp. Mn. Bhag. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in phil.) a true principle (in S&#x0101;&#x1e43;khya phil. 25 in number, viz. <em>a-vyakta</em>, <em>buddhi</em>, <em>aha&#x1e43;-k&#x0101;ra</em>, the 5 Tan-m&#x0101;tras, the 5 Mah&#x0101;-bh&#x016b;tas, the 11 organs including <em>manas</em>, and, lastly, <em>puru&#x1e63;a</em>, qq.vv.) MBh. xii, 11840 ; xiv, 984 R. iii, 53, 42 Tattvas. ; 24 in number MBh. xii, 11242 Hariv. 14840 (m.) ; 23 in number BhP. iii, 6, 2 ff </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; for other numbers <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#xi,">xi,.</a> 22, 1 ff. R&#x0101;matUp </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with M&#x0101;he&#x015b;varas and Lok&#x00e2;yatikas only 5 <em>vi&#x015b;. the 5 elements</em> are admitted Prab. ii, 18/19 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with Buddh. 4, with Jainas 2 or 5 or 7 or 9 Sarvad. ii f </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in Ved&#x00e2;nta phil. <em>tattva</em> is regarded as made up of <em>tad</em> and <em>tvam</em>, 'that <em>art</em> thou', and called <em>mah&#x0101;-v&#x0101;kya</em>, the great word by which the identity of the whole world with the one eternal Brahma [<em>tad</em>] is expressed) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the, number 25 S&#x016b;ryas. ii </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the number 24 DevibhP. &#x015a;Br. vii, 3, 1, 43 S&#x0101;y </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an element or elementary property W </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the essence or substance of anything W. <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p433-1"></a>[Page 433, Column 1]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the being that Jaim. i, 3, 24 Sch </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>tata-tva</em> L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a musical instrument L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>ena</em>), instr. ind. according to the true state or nature of anything, in truth, truly, really, accurately Mn. vii, 68 MBh. R </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-kaumud&#x012b;</em> f. 'Tattva-moonlight', N. of a Comm. on S&#x0101;&#x1e43;khyak. Sarvad. xiv, 20 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-candra</em> m. 'truthmoon', N. of a Comm. on Prakriy&#x0101;-kaumud&#x012b; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'Tattva-moon', N. of a Comm. on <em>-kaumud&#x012b;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-cint&#x0101;ma&#x1e47;i</em> m. N. of a philos. work by Ga&#x1e45;g&#x00ea;&#x015b;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of another work Nir&#x1e47;ayas. iii </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-j&#x00f1;a</em> mfn. ifc. knowing the truth, knowing the true nature of, knowing thoroughly Mn.xii, 102 MBh. (<em>a-</em> neg., xii, 6623) R. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. a Br&#x0101;hman Npr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-j&#x00f1;&#x0101;na</em> n. knowledge of truth, thorough knowledge, insight into the true principles of phil. Sarvad </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-j&#x00f1;&#x0101;nin</em> mfn. = <em>-j&#x00f1;a</em> W </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-tara&#x1e43;gi&#x1e47;&#x012b;</em> f. 'truth-river', N. of wk. by Dharmas&#x0101;gara </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-tas</em> ind.= <em>&#x25cb;ttvena</em> Mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;Up. i, 2, 13 Mn. MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-t&#x0101;</em> f. truth, reality W </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-tyaj</em> mfn. mistaking the true state Viddh. iii, 19 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-trayamaya</em> mfn. consisting of the 3 realities Hcat. i, 11, 893 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-dar&#x015b;a</em> m. (= <em>-d&#x1e5b;&#x015b;</em>) N. of a &#x1e5a;ishi under Manu Deva-s&#x0101;var&#x1e47;i BhP. viii, 13, 32 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-dar&#x015b;in</em> mfn. = <em>-d&#x1e5b;&#x015b;</em> MBh. iii, 1149 R&#x0101;mag </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; of a Br&#x0101;hman, 1265 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-d&#x012b;pana</em> n. 'Tattva-light', N. of wk </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-d&#x1e5b;&#x015b;</em> mfn. perceiving truth Ved&#x00e2;ntas </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>tath&#x0101; prayatnam &#x0101;ti&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;hed yath&#x00e2;tm&#x0101;na&#x1e43; na p&#x012b;&#x1e0d;ayet</em>, 'he should so make effort as that he may not injure himself.' Mn. vii, 68 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; of <em>yena</em> Kath&#x0101;s. iii, 18 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of <em>y&#x0101;d&#x1e5b;&#x015b;a</em> Mn. i, 42 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; used in forms of adjuration, e.g. <em>yath&#x00e2;ham anya&#x1e43; na cintaye tath&#x00e2;yam patat&#x0101;&#x1e43; k&#x1e63;udra&#x1e25; par&#x00e2;su&#x1e25;</em>, 'as surely as I do not think on any other man, so surely let this wretch fall dead' Nal. xi, 36) RV. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; yes, so be it, so it shall be (particle of assent, agreement, or promise </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; generally followed by <em>iti</em>) AV. iii, 4, 5 &#x015a;Br. AitBr. &amp;c. (<em>tath&#x00ea;ty uktv&#x0101;</em>, having said 'so be it' or 'yes' Nal. &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; so also, in like manner (e.g. <em>sukha&#x1e43; seved du&#x1e25;kha&#x1e43; tath&#x0101;</em>, 'let him make use of prosperity and also adversity') Mn. MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>tath&#x0101; hi</em> Nal. xix, 25</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; tath&#x0101; ca </dt>
           <dd><em>t&#x00e1;th&#x0101; ca</em> and likewise, accordingly (introducing quotations) Mn. ix, 19 and 45 Dh&#x016b;rtas. Hit</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; tath&#x0101;pi </dt>
           <dd><em>t&#x00e1;th&#x00e2;pi</em> even thus, even so, nevertheless, yet, still, notwithstanding (correlative of <em>yady api</em> [R. iii, 3, 3 Dh&#x016b;rtas. &amp;c.], <em>api</em> <em>&#x0101;mar.</em>, <em>api yadi</em> <em>Prab.</em>, <em>k&#x0101;mam</em> <em>"&#x1e63;ak.</em>, <em>varam</em>) MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>tath&#x00e2;pi tu</em> id. &#x015a;ak</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; tath&#x0101; hi </dt>
           <dd><em>t&#x00e1;th&#x0101; hi</em> (g. <em>svar-&#x0101;di</em>) for so, for thus (it has been said), for instance Ragh. &#x015a;ak. &amp;c</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; tad </dt>
           <dd><em>t&#x00e1;d</em> (nom. and acc. sg. n. of and base in comp. for 2. <em>t&#x00e1;</em> from which latter all the cases of this pron. are formed except nom. sg. m. <em>s&#x00e1;s</em> or <em>s&#x00e1;</em> &amp; f. <em>s&#x0101;&#x0341;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; instr. pl. <em>ta&#x00ed;s</em> AV. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Ved. <em>t&#x00e9;bhis</em> RV. AV. &amp;c.) m. he, f. she, n. it, that, this (often correlative of <em>y&#x00e1;</em> generally standing in the preceding clause, e.g. <em>yasya buddhi&#x1e25; sa balav&#x0101;n</em>, 'of whom there is intellect he is strong' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes, for the sake of emphasis, connected with the 1st and 2nd personal pronouns, with other demonstratives and with relatives, e.g. <em>so'ham</em>, 'I that very person, I myself' [<em>tasya</em> = <em>mama</em> Nal. xv, 10] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>t&#x0101;v imau</em>, 'those very two' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>tad etad &#x0101;khy&#x0101;nam</em>, 'that very tale' AitBr. vii, 18 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>yat tat k&#x0101;ra&#x1e47;am</em>, 'that very reason which' Mn. i, 11 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>y&#x0101; s&#x0101; &#x015b;r&#x012b;</em>, 'that very fortune which' MBh. vii, 427) RV. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>tad</em>), n. this world (cf. <em>idam</em>) R. vi, 102, 25 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = Brahma, <em>tat-tva</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>t&#x00e1;d</em>), ind. there, in that place, thither, to that spot (correlative of <em>y&#x00e1;tra</em> or <em>y&#x00e1;tas</em>) AV. AitBr. ii, 11 &#x015a;Br. i, x, xiv ChUp </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; then, at that time, in that case (correlative of <em>yad&#x0101;&#x0341;</em>, <em>y&#x00e1;d</em> AV </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of <em>y&#x00e1;tra</em> &#x015a;Br. xiv </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of <em>yadi</em> Nal. Bhag. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of <em>c&#x00ea;d</em> &#x015a;ak. &amp;c.) RV. iv, 28, 1 AV. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; thus, in this manner, with regard to that, ix, xiii &#x015a;Br. AitBr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>tad etau &#x015b;lokau bhavata&#x1e25;</em>, 'with reference to that there are these two verses') Pra&#x015b;nUp </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; on that account, for that reason, therefore, consequently (sometimes correlative of <em>yatas</em>, <em>yad</em>, <em>yena</em>, 'because' Da&#x015b;. Pa&#x00f1;cat. Kath&#x0101;s. &amp;c.) Mn. ix, 41 MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; now (clause-connecting particle) AV. xv &#x015a;Br. AitBr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; so also, equally, and AV. xi, xv</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; tad tad </dt>
           <dd><em>tad tad</em> this and that, various, different (e.g. <em>ta&#x1e43; ta&#x1e43; de&#x015b;a&#x1e43; jag&#x0101;ma</em>, 'he went to this and that place' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>t&#x0101;su t&#x0101;su yoni&#x1e63;u</em>, 'in different or various birth-places' Mn. xii, 74) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; respective B&#x1e5b;N&#x0101;rP. xiii, 88 </dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; yad tad </dt>
           <dd><em>yad tad</em> whosoever, whichsoever, any, every (also with <em>v&#x0101;</em> Mn. xii, 68 [<em>yad v&#x0101; tad v&#x0101;</em>, 'this or that, any'] Hariv. 5940 Dh&#x016b;rtas. &#x015a;ak. Sch </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; often both pronouns repeated or the interrogative pron. with <em>cid</em> added after the relative, e.g. <em>yad-yat para-va&#x015b;a&#x1e43; karma tat-tad varjayet</em>, 'whatever action depends on another, that he should avoid' Mn. iv, 159 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>yat ki&#x1e43;-cid-tad</em>, 'whatever-that' Mn.)</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (said of a speech or hymn) accomplished (in metre) RV. viii, 1, 18 and (acc. f. <em>&#x25cb;nv&#x00e1;m</em>) 76, 12 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>us</em>), f. (once m.            <dt>tap 1</dt>
           <dd><em>tap</em> (cf. &#x221a;1. <em>pat</em>), cl. 4. &#x0100;. <em>&#x25cb;pyate</em>, to rule Dh&#x0101;tup. xxvi, 50</dd>

           <dt>tap 2</dt>
           <dd><em>tap</em> cl. 1. <em>t&#x00e1;pati</em> (rarely &#x0100; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Subj. <em>&#x25cb;p&#x0101;ti</em> RV. v, 79, 9 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>t&#x00e1;pat</em> RV. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cl. 4. p. <em>t&#x00e1;pyat</em> VS. xxxix, 12 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. 1. sg. <em>tat&#x00e1;pa</em> RV. vii, 104, 15 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 3. sg. <em>&#x25cb;t&#x0101;&#x0341;pa</em>, x, 34, 11 AV. vii, 18, 2 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>tep&#x0101;n&#x00e1;</em> RV </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>tapsy&#x00e1;ti</em> Br. &amp;c.: <em>&#x25cb;te</em> &amp; <em>tapi&#x1e63;yati</em> MBh.) to give out heat, be hot, shine (as the sun) RV. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to make hot or warm, heat, shine upon ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to consume or destroy by heat ib </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to suffer pain MBh. viii, 1794 G&#x012b;t. vii, 31 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>pa&#x015b;c&#x0101;t</em>) to repent of MBh. viii, 39, 15 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to torment one's self, undergo self-mortification, practise austerity (<em>tapas</em>) TUp. ii, 6 Mn. i f. MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause pain to, injure, damage, spoil RV. AitBr. vii, 17 &#x015a;Br. xiv &amp;c.: Pass. or cl. 4. &#x0100;. <em>tapy&#x00e1;te</em> (xiv </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or <em>t&#x00e1;py&#x25cb;</em> TBr. ii </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>&#x25cb;py&#x00e1;m&#x0101;na</em> AV </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>t&#x00e1;py&#x25cb;</em>, xix, 56, 5 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>&#x00e1;-</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>at&#x0101;pi</em> RV. vii, 70, 2 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>atapta</em> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 3-1, 65 K&#x0101;&#x015b; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>tepe</em> MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>&#x25cb;p&#x0101;n&#x00e1;</em> &#x015a;Br </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also P. <em>tapyati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;pyet</em>, <em>atapyat</em>, &amp;c. MBh. R. Kath&#x0101;s. x, 4) to be heated or burnt, become hot RV. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be purified by austerities (as the soul) Sarvad </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to suffer or feel pain RV. x, 34, 10 and 95, 17 AV. xix, 56, 5 &#x015a;Br. xiv MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to suffer pain voluntarily, undergo austerity (<em>tapas</em>) AV. &#x015a;Br. TBr. &#x1e62;a&#x1e0d;vBr. &#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r. &amp;c.: Caus. <em>t&#x0101;payati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (p. <em>&#x25cb;p&#x00e1;yat</em> AV </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pass. <em>&#x25cb;pyate</em> MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>at&#x012b;tape</em> &amp; <em>&#x1e63;ubj.</em> <em>tat&#x00e1;pate</em> RV.) to make warm or hot, iv, 2, 6 ; viii, 72, 4 Kau&#x015b;. MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to consume by heat R. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause pain, trouble, distress AV. xix, 28, 2 MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to torment one's self, undergo penance, iii, 8199: Intens. (p. <em>t&#x0101;tapyam&#x0101;na</em>) to feel violent pain, be in great anxiety R. i, 11, 8 BhP. ii, 7, 24 ; [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Lat">Lat.</a> <em>tepeo</em> &amp;c.]</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; tap 3</dt>
           <dd><em>tap</em> mfn. 'warming one's self.' <em>agni-t&#x00e1;p</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; tapa </dt>
           <dd><em>tapa</em> mfn. ifc. 'consuming by heat', <em>lal&#x0101;&#x1e6d;am-</em> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; the sun W </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>&#x25cb;pas</em>, religious austerity Car. C&#x0101;&#x1e47;. (cf. <em>mah&#x0101;-</em> and <em>su-</em>) </dd>

           <dd><em>t&#x00e1;mas</em> n. darkness, gloom (also pl.) RV. (<em>&#x25cb;ma&#x1e25;</em>, <em>pr&#x00e1;&#x1e47;&#x012b;ta</em>, 'led into darkness, 'deprived of the eye's light or sight, i, 117, 17) &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the darkness of hell, hell or a particular division of hell Mn. iv, viii f. VP. ii, 6, 4 M&#x0101;rkP. xii, 10 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the obscuration of the sun or moon in eclipses, attributed to R&#x0101;hu (also m. L.) R. VarB&#x1e5b;S. v, 44 VarB&#x1e5b;. ii VarYogay. S&#x016b;ryas </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; mental darkness, ignorance, illusion, error (in S&#x0101;&#x1e43;khya phil. one of the 5 forms of <em>a-vidj&#x0101;</em> MBh. xiv, 1019 S&#x0101;&#x1e43;khyak. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; one of the 3 qualities or constituents of everything in creation [the cause of heaviness, ignorance, illusion, lust, anger, pride, sorrow, dulness, and stolidity </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sin L </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sorrow Kir. iii </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>gu&#x1e47;a</em> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. 45] Mn. xii, 24 f. and 38 S&#x0101;&#x1e43;khyak. &amp;c.) RV. v. 31, 9 R. ii &#x015a;ak. R&#x0101;jat. v, 144 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a son (of &#x015a;ravas MBh. xiii, 2002 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of Daksha, i Sch </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of P&#x1e5b;ithu-&#x015b;ravas VP. iv, 12, 2) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; [cf. <em>timira</em> ; Lat. <em>temere</em> &amp;c.]</dd>

           <dt>tara 1</dt>
           <dd><em>tara</em> an affix forming the compar. degree of adjectives and rarely (cf. <em>v&#x1e5b;tra-t&#x00e1;ra</em>) of substantives Su&#x015b;r. i, 20, 11 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;m</em>), added (in older language) to adverbs ( <em>ati-tar&#x0101;&#x0341;m</em> &amp;c.) and (in later language) to verbs (Pa&#x00f1;cat. i, 14, 7 Ratn&#x00e2;v. iii, 9 Kath&#x0101;s.), intensifying their meaning </dd>

           <dt>tara 2</dt>
           <dd><em>t&#x00e1;ra</em> mfn. (&#x221a;<em>t&#x1e5d;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; g. <em>pac&#x00e2;di</em>) carrying across or beyond, saving (?, said of &#x015a;iva) MBh. xii, 10380 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ifc. passing over or beyond W </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'surpassing, conquering', <em>&#x015b;oka-tar&#x00e1;</em>, cf. <em>ratha&#x1e43;tar&#x00e1;</em> </dd>

           <dt>t&#x0101;la </dt>
           <dd><em>t&#x0101;la</em> m. (Siddhnapu&#x1e43;s. 25 Sch.) the palmyra tree or fan-palm (Borassus flabelliformis, producing a sort of spirituous liquor </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; t&#x0101;vat </dt>
           <dd><em>t&#x0101;&#x0341;vat</em> mf(<em>at&#x012b;</em>)n. (fr. 2. <em>ta</em> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 5-2, 39 ; vi, 3, 91) so great, so large, so much, so far, so long, so many (correlative of <em>y&#x0101;&#x0341;vat</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; rarely of <em>ya</em> or <em>yath&#x00f4;kta</em> Nal.&amp;c.) RV. &amp;c. (<em>y&#x0101;vat&#x0101; k&#x1e63;a&#x1e47;ena t&#x0101;vat&#x0101;</em>, 'after so long time, in that time', as soon as R&#x0101;jat. v, 110) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; just a little Kir. ii, 48 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in alg.) an unknown quantity (also with <em>y&#x0101;vat</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind. (correlative of <em>y&#x0101;&#x0341;vat</em>) so much, so greatly, to such an extent, in such a number, so far RV. AV. &amp;c. (<em>t&#x0101;&#x0341;vat-t&#x0101;vat</em> &#x015a;Br. i, 8, 1, 6) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; so long, in that time RV. x, 88, 19 &#x015a;Br. i Mn. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; meanwhile, in the mean time (the correlative <em>y&#x0101;vat</em> being often connected with a neg., e.g. <em>t&#x0101;vac chobhate m&#x016b;rkho y&#x0101;vat ki&#x1e43;-cin na bh&#x0101;&#x1e63;ate</em>, 'so long a fool shines as long as he says nothing' Hit </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x015b;ocayi&#x1e63;y&#x0101;my &#x0101;tm&#x0101;na&#x1e43; t&#x0101;vad y&#x0101;van me pr&#x00e2;ptam br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;yam</em>, 'so long I will emaciate myself, as long as <em>i.e. until</em> I have obtained the state of a Br&#x0101;hman' R. i, 64, 19) &#x015a;Br. xiv, 4, 2, 30 ChUp. vi, 14, 2 Mn. MBh. &amp;c. (also correlative of <em>pur&#x0101;</em> [R. i, 28, 21], of <em>y&#x0101;vat&#x0101; na</em>, of <em>y&#x0101;vat</em> preceded by <em>pur&#x0101;</em> [MBh. xiii, 4556], or without any correlative <em>2727 Kath&#x0101;s. &#x1e25;it.</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; at once, now, just, first (followed by <em>anantaram</em> <em>&#x1e25;it.</em>, <em>aparam</em> <em>Pa&#x00f1;cat.</em>, <em>api</em> <em>ib.</em>, <em>id&#x0101;n&#x012b;m</em> <em>&#x1e25;it.</em>, <em>uta</em> <em>"&#x1e63;ak.</em>, <em>ca</em> <em>&#x1e0d;a&#x015b;. Prab.</em>, <em>tatas</em> [Mn. iv, 174 Ragh. vii, 4f.], <em>tad-anu</em> <em>&#x1e43;egh.</em>, <em>tu</em> <em>&#x1e0d;a&#x015b;.vii Ved&#x00e2;ntas.</em>, <em>pa&#x015b;c&#x0101;t</em> <em>&#x1e5b;. &#x012b;</em>, <em>punar</em> <em>Pa&#x00f1;cat.</em>, <em>v&#x0101;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; very often connected with an Impv., rarely [MBh. iv, 888 R. ii, 56, 13] with a Pot., often with the 1st person of pr. or fut. MBh. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the Impv. is sometimes to be supplied [<em>itas t&#x0101;vat</em>, 'just come hither' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101; t&#x0101;vat</em>, 'by no means, God forbid!'] &#x015a;ak. M&#x0101;lav. Vikr. Prab </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes <em>arhasi</em> with the inf. is used instead R. i f.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>na</em> or <em>a-</em>) not yet MBh. &amp;c. (followed by <em>y&#x0101;vat</em>, 'while' Kath&#x0101;s. xxvi, 23 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>t&#x0101;van na-ap4i na</em>, 'not only not-but also not' K&#x0101;d.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; very well, all right Hcar </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; indeed, truly (e.g. <em>d&#x1e5b;&#x1e0d;has t&#x0101;vad bandha&#x1e25;</em>, 'the knot is tight I must admit' Hit </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>gat&#x0101; t&#x0101;vat</em>, 'she is indeed gone' Kath&#x0101;s. xviii, 241) R. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; already (opposed to 'how much more' or 'how much less') R. iv f. &#x015a;ak </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; really (= <em>eva</em>, sometimes connected with this particle, e.g. <em>vikrayas t&#x0101;vad eva sa&#x1e25;</em>, 'it is really a sale') Mn. iii, 53 Hariv. 7110 R. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>t&#x0101;</em>), instr. ind. to that extent RPr&#x0101;t. xiii, 13 BhP. v, viii </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in that time, in the mean time, meanwhile Da&#x015b;. Kath&#x0101;s. x, 24 Bhara&#x1e6d; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>ti</em>), loc, ind. so far &#x015a;Br. viii, 6, 2, 8 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e63;y&#x0101;</em> L </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; strong desire L </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; t&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;&#x0101; </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; the bright appearance of the human body (in health), beauty Nal. Su&#x015b;r. i, 15 <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p454-3"></a>[Page 454, Column 3]</font> </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;sa&#x1e43;hit&#x0101;</em> f. the Sa&#x1e43;hit&#x0101; of the Taittir&#x012b;yas (chief recension of the Black YV., on the origin of which VP. iii, 5, 1-29 has the following legend: the YV. was first taught by Vai&#x015b;amp&#x0101;yana to 27 pupils, among whom was Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;avalkya </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; subsequently V. being offended with Y. bade him disgorge the Veda committed to him, which he did in a tangible form </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; whereupon the older disciples of V. being commanded to pick it up, took the form of partridges, and swallowed the soiled texts, hence named 'black' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the other name <em>taittir&#x012b;ya</em> referring to the partridges. Y. then received from the Sun a new or white version of the YV., called from Y.'s patr. <em>v&#x0101;jasaneyin</em>)</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; on Vasish&#x1e6d;ha's refusing he applied to Vasish&#x1e6d;ha's hundred sons, who cursed and degraded him to the rank of a Ca&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;&#x0101;la <em>hence called a Ca&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;&#x0101;la king &#x1e0d;ivy&#x00e2;v. xxxiii</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Vi&#x015b;v&#x0101;-mitra then undertook the sacrifice for him and invited all the gods, who declined to come and thereby so enraged the sage that, by his own power, he transported Telinga to heaven </dd>

           <dd><em>trika&#x012b;7ka</em> m. = <em>ekatrika</em> &#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r. xiv, 42, 7</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; trica </dt>
           <dd><em>tric&#x00e1;</em> <em>t&#x1e5b;c&#x00e1;</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; trita </dt>
           <dd><em>trit&#x00e1;</em> m. 'third' (?), N. of a Vedic deity (associated with the Maruts, V&#x0101;yu, and Indra </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fighting like the latter with Tv&#x0101;sh&#x1e6d;ra, V&#x1e5b;itra, and other demons </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; called &#x0100;ptya [q.v.), 'water-deity', and supposed to reside in the remotest regions of the world, whence [RV. viii, 47, 13-15 AV.] the idea of wishing to remove calamity to T&#x1e6d;Tv&#x0101;sh&#x1e6d;ra, and the view of the Tritas being the keepers of nectar [RV. vi, 44, 23], similarly L. RV. ii, 34, 10 TS. i TBr. i] the notion of Trita's bestowing long life </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also conceived as an inferior deity conquering the demons by order and with the help of Indra [RV. ii ; viii, 52, 1 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; x] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fallen into a well he begged aid from the gods [i, 105, 17 ; x, 8, 7] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; as to this last myth S&#x0101;y. on i, 105 relates that 3 &#x1e5a;ishis, Ekata, Dvita, and Trita, parched with thirst, looked about and found a well, and when Tv&#x0101;sh&#x1e6d;ra began to draw water, the other two, desirous of his property, pushed him down and closed up the well with a wheel </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; shut up there, Tv&#x0101;sh&#x1e6d;ra composed a hymn to the gods, and managed miraculously to prepare the sacrificial Soma, that he might drink it himself, or offer it to the deities and so be extricated: this is alluded to in RV. ix, 34, 4 [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#32,">32,.</a> 2 ; 38, 2 ; 102, 2] and described in MBh. ix, 2095 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also Nir. iv, 6 makes him a &#x1e5a;ishi, and he is the supposed author of RV. i, 105 ; viii, 36 ; ix, 33 f. and 102 ; x, 1-7 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in epic legends [MBh. ix, xii f. ] Ekata, Dvita, and T&#x1e6d;Tv&#x0101;sh&#x1e6d;ra are described as 3 brothers, sons of Gautama or of Praj&#x0101;-pati or Brahm&#x0101; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; elsewhere Tv&#x0101;sh&#x1e6d;ra is one of the 12 sons of Manu C&#x0101;kshusha by Na&#x1e0d;val&#x0101; BhP. iv, 13, 16 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>traitan&#x00e1;</em> ; Zd. <em>&#x1e6d;hrita</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ?, ?, &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. triplet of young (three-twin) TS. Sch</dd>
